messageBody:
Jean-François Colson scripsit:

> When they call each other by phone, can’t they understand one another?
> Of course they can.

Certainly (up to a point, which I will not worry about at present: there
are some accents that are *not* easily mutually intelligible, though
they are connected by intermediate accents). But writing is not speech.
In writing, we have far less context available for understanding, though
admittedly we can back up and try again if we don't get it the first time.
Too much of that, however, and the reader is likely to give up.

> Why couldn’t they read others’ dialects?

For one thing, because fluent readers in any language read words by their
shape, not by trying to sound them out, unless they have never seen that
written word before. By the same token, publishers do not want to deal
with "diw", "dew", "jew", and "doo" spellings for the same word: they
want a single spelling that copy editors (or spell checkers) can verify.
Even in Early Modern English days, where standards were not universal,
the real irregularities were found at the periphery of writing (as
they are today: look at YouTube comments), not in the broad mainstream.
Shakespeare's name was written in thirty-odd ways including "Shaxpur"
and "Shagsper", but a plurality of scribes wrote "Shakespeare", as we
do today, and almost all of those who worked in London (the home of
publishing and literacy in England then) used that form exclusively.

No language that I know of has ever spread mass literacy among its
speakers without a standardized orthography. (Some languages have
a few standardized orthographies, usually only trivially different,
for historical/political reasons.) That said, there are two choices.
One is to pick an accent and privilege it, making everyone read and
write as if they spoke that accent (in the case of Modern English,
the privileged accent is from the 14th century, so no accent is fully
privileged, though some have more privilege than others). If we are going
to reform English spelling at all, I think we need worldwide acceptance,
which means accepting in turn that no one accent dominates all others
socially (not true of all languages, but emphatically true of English).

Alternatively, we can design a diaphonemic orthography that allows all
(or almost all) accents to make the distinctions they need, and which
is sufficiently aligned so that all (or almost all) words are written
the same way in all (or almost all) accents.

This entails in general that if people wish to be understood, they must
often learn to make distinctions in writing that they don't make in speech
(thus Bob from California must learn when to write Ah, when Awe, and
when Ox, though they all sound the same to him); to omit distinctions
in writing that they do make in speech (thus Laurie in New York City
needs to write "can" (be able) and "can" (metal container) both with Ash,
though they don't sound the same to her); and occasionally to write the
"wrong thing" from the perspective of speech (thus Frank from Chicago
needs to write "bag" with Ash, not with Age, though that's not the way
it sounds to him).

Orthographic development is hard; let's go shopping.

--
